Hi all, I want to propose design document for Power Management application which follows chapter 6.6 of DCMI specification to monitor and control total power consumption.
Please help me to review this document.

Thanks
Adding Chris and Martha from IBM who I think own the design on the existing power management application.
Done
I thought IBM had something implemented for this?
I see that IBM team implemented an application which controls CPU's power via OCC device. This design implements an application that follows DCMI specification which are not depended on the hardware.
Done

The OCC (On Chip Controller) provides power monitoring and control.
https://github.com/open-power/docs/tree/P10/occ

The OCC is always monitoring the power usage to ensure it is within the system power capacity.  If the system power usage goes over that limit for a period of time, the system will be moved to a safe mode (reduced power and performance).
Safe mode is defined to allow the system to continue safe system operation without shutting the system off.

The openpower-occ-control app is responsible for communicating with the OCC and reporting the thermal and power sensor data.

Thank you for your information, but if the system does not have the OCC device, we can not use openpower-occ-control app. This design follows DCMI specification which are not depended on the hardware, we can apply this solution anywhere.
Done

A user power cap can also be specified via GUI or Redfish.
The OCC will then create a PEL if the system exceeds that user specified power cap.
This is intended on being a power saving feature, not for system protection, so I don't think this would be a reason to power off a system.

Here is the user power limit (PowerCap / PowerCapEnable properties): 
```# busctl introspect xyz.openbmc_project.Settings /xyz/openbmc_project/control/host0/power_cap
NAME                                  TYPE      SIGNATURE RESULT/VALUE FLAGS
org.freedesktop.DBus.Introspectable   interface -         -            -
.Introspect                           method    -         s            -
org.freedesktop.DBus.Peer             interface -         -            -
.GetMachineId                         method    -         s            -
.Ping                                 method    -         -            -
org.freedesktop.DBus.Properties       interface -         -            -
.Get                                  method    ss        v            -
.GetAll                               method    s         a{sv}        -
.Set                                  method    ssv       -            -
.PropertiesChanged                    signal    sa{sv}as  -            -
xyz.openbmc_project.Control.Power.Cap interface -         -            -
.MaxPowerCapValue                     property  u         2777         emits-change writable
.MinPowerCapValue                     property  u         1778         emits-change writable
.MinSoftPowerCapValue                 property  u         556          emits-change writable
.PowerCap                             property  u         1000         emits-change writable
.PowerCapEnable                       property  b         false        emits-change writable```
And via Redfish: /redfish/v1/Chassis/chassis/EnvironmentMetrics
```    "PowerLimitWatts": {
        "AllowableMax": 2777,
        "AllowableMin": 1778,
        "ControlMode": "Disabled",
        "SetPoint": 1000
    }```

The OCC is always monitoring the power to ensure it is within the system power limit. Again if consumption exceeds the system power limit (AllowableMax property), it is moved to safe mode to keep the hardware safe but still operational.
The safe mode only is available on the OCC device, if the system does not have OCC device, we should turn off the host or make OEM action (Users can implement a simulated "safe mode" in this mode).

Still trying to understand difference between standard and enhanced.
Seems like you really only need one mode and it either has 1 entry or multiple.
In standard mode you lock the units as ms.  Does that mean the user can set it to 10ms, and samples will be taken every 10ms?

> Still trying to understand difference between standard and enhanced.
> Seems like you really only need one mode and it either has 1 entry or multiple.

The different between 2 modes are number of options and the units in each mode.
- Standard: 1 option and the units has to be "milliseconds"
- Enhanced: 0 or multiple option and the units can be "seconds/minutes/hours/days" (not includes "milliseconds")

Those information are based on the chapter 6.6.1 of DCMI specification. I updated this information to make it clearly.

> In standard mode you lock the units as ms.  Does that mean the user can set it to 10ms, and samples will be taken every 10ms?

When user configure the standard mode has the Duration is 10ms, it means the timeframe of this option is 10ms, not the sampling periodic of Power-monitor. The sampling periodic is configured based on "SamplingPeriod" property of "xyz.openbmc_project.Control.Power.Cap" interface.

> When user configure the standard mode has the Duration is 10ms, it means the timeframe of this option is 10ms, not the sampling periodic of Power-monitor.

I thought the sampling period was for Power Limit detection.


I looked at 6.6 of DCMI spec and think I understand better.  I think you can update the wording to match the DCMI spec to help clarify here. (6.6.5.2 examples were helpful)  or even reference the DCMI spec directly here.

Standard mode provides a non-periodic sampling of the power readings
Enhanced mode provides a periodic rolling average of power readings over one or more sampling periods.

Statistics reporting time period:
For Standard Mode Timeframe in milliseconds, over which the controller collects
statistics
For Enhanced Mode Timeframe reflects the Averaging Time period in units.
Thank you for your information, I will investigate 6.6.5.2 section more and update document later

What do you think about the purpose of "Management application Statistics Sampling period in seconds" parameter in the "Set/Get Power Limit" commands @Chris?

I see in the "Set Power Limit" command, it said that "The power limit sampling interval is the same as that for the Get Power Reading command" about "Correction Time Limit in milliseconds", therefore, "Management application Statistics Sampling period in seconds" maybe not the sampling period to check power limit.

From my reading of the spec:
The sampling interval of the Get Power Reading command is based on the current mode (standard / enhanced)
I would interpret that "sampling interval" statement as the power limit will be reading a new power value at the same interval as specified in the sampling period.

The correction time is how long it needs to be over the limit before considering the limit to have been exceeded.
I would assume if the Correction Time limit is less than the sampling interval, then the power would still be read at the Correction Time interval, but the comment in the spec seems to imply that the readings are only done on the sampling interval.

I have another understanding about this issue.
Both Power-limit and Power-monitor have the same "sampling interval", this is a fixed value (at least 1s). 2 features use "sampling interval" as below:
- Power-limit: Read the new system's power after "sampling interval" then compare to the configured power limit value.
- Power-monitor: Read the new system's power after "sampling interval" then store in the buffer.
Power-monitor calculates the Statistics base on the buffer and the "Management application Statistics Sampling period in seconds", it means that Power-monitor does not get all of elements in the buffer, it only gets element each "Statistics Sampling period"

Example:
"sampling interval" = 0,5s.
"Management application Statistics Sampling period in seconds" = 2s.
Standard mode has timeframe is 100000ms (10s).
Enhanced mode has timeframe is 60s.
Power-limit shall read the system's power each 0,5s then compare it with the configured power limit.
Power-monitor shall read the system's power each 0,5s then store to the buffer.
- When users request to read Statistics in standard mode, Power-monitor shall get the 5 samples from current time in the buffer (the gap between of samples is 2s not 0,5s). Power-monitor calculate Statistics via those 5 samples.
- When users request to read Statistics in Enhanced mode, Power-monitor shall get the 30 samples from current time in the buffer (the gap between of samples is 2s not 0,5s). Power-monitor calculate Statistics via those 30 samples.
That looks correct to me.
I added "Sampling behavior" Section to describe more detail about the behavior of features. Please take a look.

Hi Thang, thanks for working to reach consensus on this with Chris. I have a couple of minor queries.
Thank you for your comments, please find out my answer as below.
But why is this not what you're proposing? Why is your proposal better?

The Telemetry provides a solution for monitoring Max/Min/Avg/Current values of sensors. But as I investigate, when users create a report, Telemetry creates a buffer to store reading values. If we use the Telemetry to monitor total power consumption with the multiple time frame options (1 day, 2 hours, 3 days ...), so many buffers will be created to store reading values. In the power-manager, we create one buffer to support multiple time frame options.

Beside that, the minimum of Interval is 1000ms (but in Power-monitoring, we expect the maximum of Interval is 1000ms).

Okay, thanks. Note you can maybe avoid doing that by taking the argument that the telemetry app probably shouldn't be adjusting system power-caps. That seems like a reasonable justification to me if it makes sense to you.

The power-manager application has 2 features: Power Limit and Power Monitoring.
The Telemetry repo is concerned to handle Power Monitoring features, not whole power-manager application. So I have to investigate Telemetry to answer your questions.

Can we change the implementation of the telemetry daemon? What are the impacts of that? Is it undesirable? If so, why?

Can you please unpack the answers to these questions in the text?

> Can we change the implementation of the telemetry daemon? What are the impacts of that? Is it undesirable? If so, why?

The Telemetry design follow `Redfish Telemetry White Paper` specification (https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP2051_1.0.1.pdf). We should not modify Telemetry to adapt with power-manager application.
> 
> Can you please unpack the answers to these questions in the text?

What do you think if I update those statement to this one:
"To monitor sensor's values, the Telemetry has to create buffer to store reading values for each metric report. If users want to monitor Max/Min/Avg of a sensor in a time frame (E.g: 1 hour), users have to create 3 different metric reports, and the Telemetry has to create 3 buffers to store reading values. In case user want to monitor Max/Min/Avg total power consumption in multiple time frames (E.g: 1 hour, 5 hours, 1 day ...), the Telemetry has to create so much buffer to store reading values for each time frame. On the other side, power-manager only uses 1 buffer to store reading values of total power consumption."
Yep, let's go with that.
Done

What's the constraint that forces a minimum polling period of 1000ms? Can we make the telemetry daemon poll faster, or exploit `PropertiesChanged` signals? If that's undesirable, why?

Can you please unpack the answer to these questions in the text?

> What's the constraint that forces a minimum polling period of 1000ms? Can we make the telemetry daemon poll faster, or exploit `PropertiesChanged` signals? If that's undesirable, why?

The `Redfish Telemetry White Paper` is using `CollectionDuration` property to indicate the Interval. And this property is follow ISO 8601, the smallest time units is `seconds". You can refer to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Durations for more information.
> 
> Can you please unpack the answer to these questions in the text?

What do you think if I update it to:
"The `Redfish Telemetry White Paper` is using `CollectionDuration` property to indicate the Interval. And this property is follow ISO 8601 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Durations), the smallest time units is `seconds". Therefore the minimum of Interval is 1000ms (but in Power-monitoring, we expect the maximum of Interval is 1000ms)"
I'd take out your final parentheses, but that sounds like a good addition to me.
Done

Are there any other reasons that reworking the telemetry daemon is not desirable? For example, having the telemetry daemon adjust the system power caps feels a bit out-of-scope. If that argument makes sense, then adding it to the document would help motivate keeping the implementation out of telemetry.

The Telemetry is design to monitor sensors value, not control the power, therefore it seems updating Telemetry to control power is out-of-scope. Using Telemetry to implement power-monitor feature wastes so much resource to create buffers to store reading values. I think we should keep current implementation of Telemetry.
Sounds good. Please add that argument to the document.
Done
